title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Robotics and Automated Systems

Instructor: Aykut Satici, Ph.D.Â

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Kinematic chains


A robot manipulator is composed of a set of links connected together by joints.

Simple: revolute or prismatic with one degree-of-freedom (DoF)
Complex: universal or spherical with multiple DoF

No loss of generality considering only single DoF joints as multiple DoF joints can always be thought of as a succession of single DoF joints with links of length zero in between.
The action of each joint can be described by a single real number:

the angle of rotation in the case of a revolute joint
the displacement in the case of a prismatic joint

A robot manipulator with nn joints will have n+1n+1 links, since each joint connects two links.
Number the joints from 11 to nn and the links from 00 to nn, starting from the base.
Joint ii, which is fixed w.r.t. link iâˆ’1i-1, connects link iâˆ’1i-1 to link ii.
When joint ii is actuated, link ii moves (hence, link 00 is fixed).

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Kinematic chains



With the ithi^{\text{th}} joint, we associate a joint variable, denoted by qiq_i.

qi={Î¸iif joint i is revolutediif joint i is prismatic
q_i = \begin{cases}
    \theta_i & \mbox{if joint $i$ is revolute} \\
    d_i & \mbox{if joint $i$ is prismatic} \\
\end{cases}


We attach a coordinate frame rigidly to each link; i.e.Â Î£i\Sigma_i is attached to link ii.

the coordinates of each point on link ii are constant when expressed in Î£i\Sigma_i
Î£0\Sigma_0 is attached to the robot base, is referred to as the base frame, inertial frame, or world frame.









Coordinate frames attached to the elbow manipulator.




Suppose ğ€i\bm{A}_i is the homogeneous transformation matrix that gives the pose of Î£i\Sigma_i w.r.t. Î£iâˆ’1\Sigma_{i-1}.

The assumption that all joints are either revolute or prismatic means that

ğ€i=ğ€i(qi). \bm{A}_i = \bm{A}_i(q_i).

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Kinematic chains



The homogeneous transformation matrix that expresses the pose of Î£j\Sigma_j w.r.t. Î£i\Sigma_i is called a transformation matrix, and is denoted iğ“j{^i}\bm{T}_j.

Â 

We denote the pose of the end-effector w.r.t. the inertial frame by a 33-vector 0ğ¨n{^0}\bm{o}_n and the rotation matrix 0ğ‘n{^0}\bm{R}_n and define the homogeneous transformation matrix


iğ“j={ğ€i+1ğ€i+2â‹¯ğ€jâˆ’1ğ€jif i<jIif i=j(jğ“i)âˆ’1if j>i
{^i}\bm{T}_j = \begin{cases}
    \bm{A}_{i+1}\bm{A}_{i+2}\cdots \bm{A}_{j-1}\bm{A}_j & \mbox{if } i < j\\
    I & \mbox{if } i = j \\
    \left( {^j}\bm{T}_i \right)^{-1} & \mbox{if } j > i
\end{cases}

ğ‡=(0ğ‘n0ğ¨n01). \bm{H} = \begin{pmatrix} {^0}\bm{R}_n & {^0}\bm{o}_n \\ 0 & 1
\end{pmatrix}. 



The pose of the end-effector in the inertial frame are is thus given by the product ğ‡=0ğ“n=ğ€1(q1)ğ€2(q2)â‹¯ğ€n(qn). \bm{H} = {^0}\bm{T}_n = \bm{A}_1(q_1) \bm{A}_2(q_2) \cdots \bm{A}_n(q_n). 
Each homogeneous transformation ğ€i\bm{A}_i is of the form ğ€i=(iâˆ’1ğ‘iiâˆ’1ğ¨i01). \bm{A}_i = \begin{pmatrix} {^{i-1}}\bm{R}_i & {^{i-1}}\bm{o}_i \\ 0 & 1
\end{pmatrix}. 
Hence, for i<ji < j, iğ“j=ğ€i+1â‹¯ğ€j=(iğ‘jiğ¨j01). {^i}\bm{T}_j = \bm{A}_{i+1} \cdots \bm{A}_{j} = 
\begin{pmatrix} {^i}\bm{R}_j & {^i}\bm{o}_j \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Kinematic chains

The matrix iğ‘j{^i}\bm{R}_j expresses the orientation of Î£j\Sigma_j relative to Î£i\Sigma_i and is given by the rotational part of the ğ€\bm{A} matrices as

iğ‘j=iğ‘i+1i+1ğ‘i+2â‹¯jâˆ’1ğ‘j. {^i}\bm{R}_j = {^i}\bm{R}_{i+1} {^{i+1}}\bm{R}_{i+2} \cdots {^{j-1}}\bm{R}_j.


The coordinate vectors iğ¨j{^i}\bm{o}_j are given recursively by the formula

iğ¨j=iğ¨jâˆ’1+iğ‘jâˆ’1jâˆ’1ğ¨j. {^i}\bm{o}_j = {^i}\bm{o}_{j-1} + {^i}\bm{R}_{j-1}{^{j-1}}\bm{o}_j. 

In principle, this is all there is to forward kinematics:

Determine the functions ğ€(qi)\bm{A}(q_i),
Multiply them together as needed.

The Denavit-Hartenberg convention streamlines and simplifies this procedure.

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Denavit-Hartenberg convention

It is possible to carry out forward kinematic analysis even without respecting the Denavit-Hartenberg or DH convention.
However, the kinematic analysis of an nn-link manipulator can be extremely complex and the conventions introduced below simplify the analysis considerably.



In the DH convention, each homogeneous transformation ğ€i\bm{A}_i is represented as a product of four basic transformations where the four quantities Î¸i\theta_i, aia_i, did_i and Î±i\alpha_i are parameters associated with link ii and joint ii.



aia_i: link length
Î±i\alpha_i: link twist



did_i: link offset
Î¸i\theta_i: joint angle




ğ€i=â„›z,Î¸iğ’¯z,diğ’¯x,aiâ„›x,Î±i=(cÎ¸iâˆ’sÎ¸icÎ±isÎ¸isÎ±iaicÎ¸isÎ¸icÎ¸icÎ±iâˆ’cÎ¸isÎ±iaisÎ¸i0sÎ±icÎ±idi0001)
\begin{aligned}
    \bm{A}_i &=
    \mathcal{R}_{z,\theta_i}\mathcal{T}_{z,d_i}\mathcal{T}_{x,a_i}\mathcal{R}_{x,\alpha_i} \\
    &= \begin{pmatrix}
        c_{\theta_i} & -s_{\theta_i}c_{\alpha_i} & s_{\theta_i}s_{\alpha_i} & a_ic_{\theta_i} \\ 
        s_{\theta_i} & c_{\theta_i}c_{\alpha_i} & -c_{\theta_i}s_{\alpha_i} & a_is_{\theta_i} \\ 
        0 & s_{\alpha_i} & c_{\alpha_i} & d_i \\ 
        0 & 0 & 0 & 1
        \end{pmatrix}
\end{aligned}




Recall: the matrix ğ€i\bm{A}_i is a function of a single variable.

Three of the above four quantities are constant for a given link,
The fourth parameter, Î¸i\theta_i for a revolute joint and did_i for a prismatic joint, is the joint variable.

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Number of parameters

When we discussed rigid-body motion, we learned that an arbitrary homogeneous transformation matrix can be characterized by 66 numbers: 33 for rotation, 33 for translation.
In the DH representation, there are only four parameters: how is this possible?

Answer: While frame ii is required to be rigidly attached to link ii, we have considerable freedom in choosing the origin and the coordinate axes of the frame.
By a clever choice of the origin and the coordinate axes, it is possible to cut down the number of parameters needed from 66 to 44.







Denavit-Hartenberg Conditions




(DH1) The axis ğ±1\bm{x}_1 is perpendicular to the axis ğ³0\bm{z}_0:
(DH2) The axis ğ±1\bm{x}_1 intersects the axis ğ³0\bm{z}_0:

ğ±1âŠ¥ğ³0\bm{x}_1 \perp \bm{z}_0.
ğ±1â‹”ğ³0\bm{x}_1 \pitchfork \bm{z}_0.






aa: distance from axis ğ³0\bm{z}_0 to ğ³1\bm{z}_1, measured along ğ±1\bm{x}_1.
Î±\alpha: angle from ğ³0\bm{z}_0 to ğ³1\bm{z}_1, measured along ğ±1\bm{x}_1.






dd: distance from the origin o0o_0 to the intersection of ğ±1\bm{x}_1 with ğ³0\bm{z}_0, measured along the ğ³0\bm{z}_0.
Î¸\theta: angle from ğ±0\bm{x}_0 to ğ±1\bm{x}_1, mesaured along ğ³0\bm{z}_0.

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Assigning the coordinate frames

One can always choose the frames Î£0,â€¦,Î£n\Sigma_0, \ldots, \Sigma_n in such a way that (DH1) and (DH2) are satisfied.
Sometimes, this will require placing the origin oio_i of Î£i\Sigma_i in a location that may not be intuitively satisfying.
The choices of the coordinate frames are not unique!

However, the end result, i.e.Â the matrix 0ğ“n{^0}\bm{T}_n, will be the same! (assuming the choice of Î£0\Sigma_0 and Î£n\Sigma_n coincide for the two different coordinate frame placements.)

The choice of ğ³i\bm{z}_i is arbitrary: First, we assign the axes ğ³0,â€¦,ğ³nâˆ’1\bm{z}_0, \ldots, \bm{z}_{n-1} in an intuitively pleasing fashion: assign ğ³i\bm{z}_i to be the axis of actuation for joint i+1i+1.

if joint i+1i+1 is revolute, ğ³i\bm{z}_i is the axis of revolution of joint i+1i+1;
if joint i+1i+1 is prismatic, ğ³i\bm{z}_i is the axis of translation of joint i+1i+1.

Second we establish the base frame. This is nearly arbitrary.

Choose o0o_0 to be any point on ğ³0\bm{z}_0.
Choose ğ±0\bm{x}_0, ğ²0\bm{y}_0 in any convenient manner so long as Î£0\Sigma_0 is right-handed.

Third, we begin an iterative process in which we define Î£i\Sigma_i using frame Î£iâˆ’1\Sigma_{i-1} beginning with Î£i\Sigma_i. Three cases to consider: (i) ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1} and ğ³i\bm{z}_i are not coplanar, (ii) ğ³iâˆ’1âˆ¥ğ³i\bm{z}_{i-1} \parallel \bm{z}_i, (iii) ğ³iâˆ’1â‹”ğ³i\bm{z}_{i-1} \pitchfork \bm{z}_i.

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Assigning the coordinate frames





ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1} and ğ³i\bm{z}_i are not coplanar



There exists a unique shortest line segment from ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1} to ğ³i\bm{z}_i perpendicular to both ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1} to ğ³i\bm{z}_i.
This line segment defines ğ±i\bm{x}_i and the point where it intersects ğ³i\bm{z}_i is the origin oio_i.
Choose an axis ğ²i\bm{y}_i to form a right-handed frame.







ğ³iâˆ’1âˆ¥ğ³i\bm{z}_{i-1} \parallel \bm{z}_i (ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1} is parallel to ğ³i\bm{z}_i, therefore Î±i=0\alpha_i = 0)



There are infinitely many common normals between ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1} and ğ³i\bm{z}_i.
We are free to choose the origin oio_i at any convenient point on the ğ³i\bm{z}_i-axis.
The axis ğ±i\bm{x}_i is chosen either to be directed from oio_i to ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1} along the common normal, or as the opposite to this vector.
Common method: choose the normal that passes through oiâˆ’1o_{i-1} as the ğ±i\bm{x}_i-axis; oio_i is then the point at which this normal intersects ğ³i\bm{z}_i Â  âˆ´di=0\therefore d_i = 0.











Denavit-Hartenberg frame assignment



Â 



ğ³iâˆ’1â‹”ğ³i\bm{z}_{i-1} \pitchfork \bm{z}_i (ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1} intersects ğ³i\bm{z}_i)



Choose ğ±i\bm{x}_i normal to the plane formed by ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1} and ğ³i\bm{z}_i with a positive direction being arbitrary.
Choose the origin oio_i at the point of intersection of ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1} and ğ³i\bm{z}_i.
In this case ai=0a_i = 0.

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Assigning the coordinate frames




To complete the construction, it is necessary to specify Î£n\Sigma_n.
Î£n\Sigma_n is commonly referred to as the end effector or tool frame.
ono_n is most often placed symmetrically between the fingers of the gripper.
The unit vectors along ğ±n\bm{x}_n, ğ²n\bm{y}_n, and ğ³n\bm{z}_n are labelled as ğ§\bm{n} (normal), ğ¬\bm{s} (sliding), and ğš\bm{a} (approach), respectively.

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Summary of the DH procedure
Step 1. Â  Locate and label the joint axes: ğ³0,ğ³1,â€¦,ğ³nâˆ’1\bm{z}_0, \bm{z}_1, \ldots, \bm{z}_{n-1}.
Step 2. Â  Establish the base frame: set the origin anywhere along the ğ³0\bm{z}_0 axis. Choose ğ±0\bm{x}_0 and ğ²0\bm{y}_0 conveniently to form a right-handed frame.
Â  Â  For i=1,â€¦,nâˆ’1i = 1, \ldots, n-1, perform steps 33 to 55.
Step 3. Â  Locate the origin oio_i where the common normal to ğ³i\bm{z}_i and ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1} intersect ğ³i\bm{z}_i. If ğ³iâ‹”ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_i \pitchfork \bm{z}_{i-1}, locate oio_i at this intersection. If ğ³iâˆ¥ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_i \parallel \bm{z}_{i-1}, locate oio_i at any convenient position along ğ³i\bm{z}_i.
Step 4. Â  Establish ğ±i\bm{x}_i along the common normal between ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1} and ğ³i\bm{z}_i through oio_i, or in the direction normal to the ğ³iâˆ’1âˆ’ğ³i\bm{z}_{i-1}-\bm{z}_i plane if ğ³iâˆ’1â‹”ğ³i\bm{z}_{i-1} \pitchfork \bm{z}_i.
Step 5. Â  Establish the ğ²i\bm{y}_i to complete a right-handed frame.
Step 6. Â  Establish Î£n\Sigma_n:

If the nthn^{\text{th}} joint is revolute, set ğ³n=ğš\bm{z}_n = \bm{a} parallel to ğ³nâˆ’1\bm{z}_{n-1}. Establish the origin ono_n conveniently along ğ³n\bm{z}_n, preferably at the center of the gripper or at the tip of any tool that manipulator may be carrying. Set ğ²n=ğ¬\bm{y}_n = \bm{s} in the direction of the gripper closure, and set ğ±n=ğ§=ğ¬Ã—ğš\bm{x}_n = \bm{n} = \bm{s} \times \bm{a}. If the tool is not a simple gripper, set ğ±n\bm{x}_n and ğ²n\bm{y}_n conveniently to form a right-handed frame.

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Summary of the DH procedure
Step 7. Â  Create a table of DH parameters aia_i, did_i, Î±i\alpha_i, Î¸i\theta_i:

aia_i: distance along ğ±i\bm{x}_i from the axis ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1} to the axis ğ³i\bm{z}_i.
did_i: distance along ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1} from oiâˆ’1o_{i-1} to the intersection of the ğ±i\bm{x}_i and ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1} axes. If joints ii is prismatic, did_i is a variable.
Î±i\alpha_i: the angle from ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1} to ğ³i\bm{z}_i measured about ğ±i\bm{x}_i.
Î¸i\theta_i: the angle from ğ±iâˆ’1\bm{x}_{i-1} to ğ±i\bm{x}_i measured about ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1}. If joint ii is revolute, Î¸i\theta_i is a variable.

Step 8. Â  Form the homogeneous transformation matrices ğ€i\bm{A}_i by substituting the above parameters into ğ€i=â„›z,Î¸iğ’¯z,diğ’¯x,aiâ„›x,Î±i
\bm{A}_i =
\mathcal{R}_{z,\theta_i}\mathcal{T}_{z,d_i}\mathcal{T}_{x,a_i}\mathcal{R}_{x,\alpha_i}

Step 9. Â  Form 0ğ“n=ğ€1ğ€2â‹¯ğ€n{^0}\bm{T}_n = \bm{A}_1 \bm{A}_2 \cdots \bm{A}_n. This gives the pose of the tool frame expressed in the base coordinates.

section: Example 4: Cylindrical manipulator with spherical wrist
text:
Example 4: Cylindrical manipulator with spherical wrist



We attach a spherical wrist to the cylindrical manipulator.
Axis of rotation of joint 44 is âˆ¥\parallel to ğ³2\bm{z}_2 and thus coincides with the axis ğ³3\bm{z}_3 of the cylindrical manipulator.
Implication: we can combine the ğ“\bm{T} matrices for the cylindrical manipulator and the spherical wrist.

0ğ“6=0ğ“33ğ“6=(ğ‘ğ01).
{^0}\bm{T}_6 = {^0}\bm{T}_3{^3}\bm{T}_6 = \begin{pmatrix}\bm{R} & \bm{d} \\
\bm{0} & 1 \end{pmatrix}.

dx=c1c4s5d6âˆ’s1c5d6âˆ’s1d3dy=s1c4s5d6+c1c5d6+c1d3dz=âˆ’s4s5d6+d1+d2.
\begin{aligned}
d_x &= c_1c_4s_5d_6 - s_1c_5d_6 - s_1d_3 \\
d_y &= s_1c_4s_5d_6 + c_1c_5d_6 + c_1d_3 \\

2} + {^0}\bm{R}_2{^2}\bm{\omega}_{2,3} + \cdots +

Linear velocity



If joint ii is prismatic, it imparts a pure translation to the end-effector.
The direction of this translation is âˆ¥\parallel to ğ³iâˆ’1\bm{z}_{i-1} and the magnitude is dÌ‡i\dot{d}_i.
Thus, expressed in Î£0\Sigma_0, we obtain 0ğ¨Ì‡n=dÌ‡i0ğ‘iâˆ’1(001)âŠ¤=dÌ‡i0ğ³iâˆ’1,

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
The general inverse kinematics problem

Given a 4Ã—44 \times 4 homogeneous transformation ğ‡=(ğ‘ğ01)âˆˆğ’ğ„(3)\bm{H} = \begin{pmatrix} \bm{R} & \bm{d} \\ \bm{0} & 1 \end{pmatrix} \in \bm{SE}(3), find a solution, or possibly multiple solutions of the equation 0ğ“n(q1,â€¦,qn)=ğ€1(q1)â‹¯ğ€(qn)=ğ‡. {^0}\bm{T}_n(q_1, \ldots, q_n) = \bm{A}_1(q_1) \cdots \bm{A}(q_n) = \bm{H}.

This matrix equation has sixteen scalar equations to be solved for nn variables q1,â€¦,qnq_1, \ldots, q_n.
Four of these equations are trivial (last row of ğ‡\bm{H}) so the remaining twelve equations are ğ­ij(q1,â€¦,qn)=ğ¡ij, for
i=1,2,3,j=1,2,3,4.\bm{t}_{ij}(q_1, \ldots, q_n) = \bm{h}_{ij}, \text{  for
} \quad i = 1, 2, 3, \; \; j = 1, 2, 3, 4. 
Typically these equations are much too difficult to solve directly in closed-form.

kinematic structure of the manipulator must be exploited to get a closed-form solution.

Unlike the forward kinematics problem, the inverse kinematics problem may or may not have a solution.

Even if a solution exists, it may or may not be unique.
Since the forward kinematic equations are in general complicated nonlinear functions of the joint variables, the solutions may be difficult to obtain even when they do exist.

Once a solution is identified, it must be further checked to see whether or not it satisfies all constraints on ther anges of possible joint motions.

One solution to the eqns below is: Î¸1=Î¸2=Î¸4=Î¸6=Ï€2\theta_1 = \theta_2 = \theta_4 = \theta_6 = \frac{\pi}{2} and Î¸5=0\theta_5 = 0, d3=12d_3 = \frac{1}{2}.

0 & 1 & 0 & -0.154 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 0.763 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1
\end{pmatrix}




c1[c2(c4c5c6âˆ’s4s6)âˆ’s2s5c6]âˆ’s1(s4c5c6+c4s6)=0s1[c2(c4c5c6âˆ’s4s6)âˆ’s2s5c6]+c1(s4c5c6+c4s6)=0âˆ’s2(c4c5c6âˆ’s4s6)âˆ’c2s5c6=1c1[âˆ’c2(c4c5c6+s4s6)+s2s5s6]âˆ’s1(âˆ’s4c5s6+c4c6)=1s1[âˆ’c2(c4c5c6+s4s6)+s2s5s6]+c1(âˆ’s4c5s6+c4c6)=0s2(c4c5c6+s4c6)+c2s5s6=0c1(c2c4s5+s2c5)âˆ’s1s4s5=0s1(c2c4s5+s2c5)+c1s4s5=1âˆ’s2c4s5+c2c5=0c1s2d3âˆ’s1d2+d6(c1c2c4s5+c1c5s2âˆ’s1s4s5)=âˆ’0.154s1s2d3+c1d2+d6(c1s4s5+c2c4s1s5+c5s1s2)=0.763c2d3+d6(c2c5âˆ’c4s2s5)=0

c_1\left[ c_2(c_4c_5c_6 - s_4s_6) - s_2s_5c_6 \right] - s_1(s_4c_5c_6 + c_4s_6) &= 0 \\

-s_2(c_4c_5c_6 - s_4s_6) - c_2s_5c_6 &= 1 \\
c_1\left[ -c_2(c_4c_5c_6 + s_4s_6) + s_2s_5s_6 \right] - s_1(-s_4c_5s_6 + c_4c_6) &= 1 \\
s_1\left[ -c_2(c_4c_5c_6 + s_4s_6) + s_2s_5s_6 \right] + c_1(-s_4c_5s_6 + c_4c_6) &= 0 \\

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Numerical inverse kinematics

Letâ€™s consider an iterative, numerical algorithms for the computation of inverse kinematics.

They are increasingly popular due to the availability of high-performance computation and the advent of open-source software.
When closed-form solutions do not exist or if the manipulator is redundant, a recourse to numerical methods may be the better option.

Let ğ±dâˆˆâ„m\bm{x}^d \in \mathbb{R}^m be a vector of Cartesian coordinates: ğ±d\bm{x}^d could represent

the wrist center point (m=3m=3),
the end-effector pose using a minimal representation (m=6m=6).

Let ğŸ:â„nâ†’â„m\bm{f}: \mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^m be the forward kinematics map for an nn-link manipulator and set ğ (ğª)=ğ±dâˆ’ğŸ(ğª). \bm{g}(\bm{q}) = \bm{x}^d - \bm{f}(\bm{q}). 

Then a solution to the inverse kinematics is a configuration ğªd\bm{q}^d satisfying ğ (ğªd)=ğ±dâˆ’ğŸ(ğªd)=0. \bm{g}(\bm{q}^d) = \bm{x}^d - \bm{f}(\bm{q}^d) = \bm{0}.

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Jacobian inverse method

We expand the forward kinematics map ğŸ(ğª)\bm{f}(\bm{q}) in a Taylor series about a configuration ğªd\bm{q}^d, such that ğ±d=ğŸ(ğªd)\bm{x}^d = \bm{f}(\bm{q}^d) to obtain ğŸ(ğª)=ğŸ(ğªd)+ğ‰(ğªd)(ğªâˆ’ğªd)+h.o.t., \bm{f}(\bm{q}) = \bm{f}(\bm{q}^d) + \bm{J}(\bm{q}^d)(\bm{q} - \bm{q}^d) +
\text{h.o.t.},  where we take ğ‰=ğ‰a(ğª)\bm{J} = \bm{J}_a(\bm{q}) as the analytic Jacobian.
Neglecting h.o.t., we have ğªdâˆ’ğª=ğ‰âˆ’1(ğª)(ğ±dâˆ’ğŸ(ğª))\bm{q}^d - \bm{q} = \bm{J}^{-1}(\bm{q}) \left(\bm{x}^d - \bm{f}(\bm{q}) \right) assuming that the Jacobian is invertible.
To find a solution for ğªd\bm{q}^d, we begin with an initial guess, ğª0\bm{q}_0 and form a sequence of successive estimates, ğª0,ğª1,ğª2,â€¦\bm{q}_0, \bm{q}_1, \bm{q}_2, \ldots, as ğªk=ğªkâˆ’1+Î±kğ‰âˆ’1(ğ±dâˆ’ğŸ(ğªkâˆ’1)),k=1,2,â€¦.\bm{q}_k = \bm{q}_{k-1} + \alpha_k \bm{J}^{-1} \left(\bm{x}^d -
\bm{f}(\bm{q}_{k-1}) \right), \;\; k= 1,2,\ldots. 

The step size Î±k>0\alpha_k > 0 can be adjusted over each iteration to aid convergence.
If the Jacobian is not invertible, then one may use the pseudoinverse ğ‰â€ \bm{J}^\dagger.
For mâ‰¤nm \leq n, we define the right pseudoinverse as ğ‰â€ â‰œğ‰âŠ¤(ğ‰ğ‰âŠ¤)âˆ’1\bm{J}^\dagger \triangleq \bm{J}^\top \left(\bm{J}\bm{J}^\top\right)^{-1}





This equation is based on a first-order approximation of the inverse kinematics so only local convergence can be expected.

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Jacobian transpose method

We define an optimization problem: Â  minğªğ…(ğª)=minğª12(ğŸ(ğª)âˆ’ğ±d)âŠ¤(ğŸ(ğª)âˆ’ğ±d)\min_\bm{q} \bm{F}(\bm{q}) = \min_\bm{q} \frac{1}{2}\left( \bm{f}(\bm{q}) - \bm{x}^d \right)^\top \left( \bm{f}(\bm{q}) - \bm{x}^d \right).
The gradient of the above cost function ğ…(ğª)\bm{F}(\bm{q}) is given by: Â  âˆ‡ğ…(ğª)=ğ‰âŠ¤(ğª)(ğŸ(ğª)âˆ’ğ±d).\nabla \bm{F}(\bm{q}) = \bm{J}^\top(\bm{q}) \left( \bm{f}(\bm{q}) - \bm{x}^d \right).
A gradient descent algorithm to minimize ğ…(ğª)\bm{F}(\bm{q}) is then ğªk=ğªkâˆ’1âˆ’Î±kâˆ‡ğ…(ğª)=ğªkâˆ’1+Î±kğ‰âŠ¤(ğ±dâˆ’ğŸ(ğªkâˆ’1)),k=1,2,â€¦.\bm{q}_k = \bm{q}_{k-1} - \alpha_k \; \nabla\bm{F}(\bm{q}) = \bm{q}_{k-1} + 
\alpha_k \bm{J}^{\top} \left(\bm{x}^d - \bm{f}(\bm{q}_{k-1}) \right), \;\; 
k= 1,2,\ldots. 




Comparison of inverse and transpose methods



Jacobian transpose is easier to compute than the Jacobian inverse.
Jacobian transpose does not suffer from configuration singularities.
The converge of the Jacobian transpose method, in terms of number of iterations, may be slower than the Jacobian inverse method.

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Kinematic decoupling

For manipulators with three consecutive joint axes intersecting at a point (e.g.Â Stanford manip.), it is possible to decouple the inverse kinematics problem into two simpler problems

inverse position kinematics,
inverse orientation kinematics.

For a six-DoF manipulator with a spherical wrist the inverse kinematics problem may be separated into two simpler problems:

First finding the position of the intersection of the wrist axes (wrist center),
Then finding the orientation of the wrist.





We express the general inverse kinematics problem as two sets of equations representing the rotational and positional kinematics where ğ¨\bm{o} and ğ‘\bm{R} are the desired position and orientation of the tool frame, expressed w.r.t. Î£0\Sigma_0.


0ğ‘6(q1,â€¦,q6)=ğ‘,0ğ¨6(q1,â€¦,q6)=ğ¨.
\begin{aligned}
{^0}\bm{R}_6(q_1, \ldots, q_6) &= \bm{R}, \\
{^0}\bm{o}_6(q_1, \ldots, q_6) &= \bm{o}.
\end{aligned}




We are given ğ¨\bm{o} and ğ‘\bm{R} and the inverse kinematics problem is to solve for q1,â€¦,q6q_1, \ldots, q_6.
With a spherical wrist, the axes ğ³3\bm{z}_3, ğ³4\bm{z}_4, and ğ³5\bm{z}_5 intersect at oco_c and hence o4=o5=oco_4 = o_5 = o_c.
Often o3o_3 will also be at oco_c but this is not necessary.

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Kinematic decoupling

What is important is that the motion of the final three joints will NOT change the position of oco_c and thus the position of the wrist center is a function of only the first three joint variables.
The origin of the tool frame (whose desired location is given by ğ¨\bm{o}) is simply obtained by a translation of distance d6d_6 along ğ³5\bm{z}_5 from oco_c.
ğ³5=ğ³6\bm{z}_5 = \bm{z}_6 and the third column of ğ‘\bm{R} expressed the direction ğ³6\bm{z}_6 w.r.t. Î£0\Sigma_0. Therefore we have ğ¨=0ğ¨c+d6ğ‘[001]âŠ¤. \bm{o} = {^0}\bm{o}_c + d_6 \bm{R} 
\;\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}^\top. 




In order to have the end-effector of the robot at the point with coordinates given by ğ¨\bm{o} and with the orientation given by ğ‘\bm{R}, it is necessary and sufficient that the wrist center oco_c have the coordinates

and the orientation of the frame Î£6\Sigma_6 w.r.t. Î£0\Sigma_0 be given by ğ‘\bm{R}.

If the components of ğ¨\bm{o} are denoted oxo_x, oyo_y, ozo_z and the components of 0ğ¨c{^0}\bm{o}_c are denoted by xcx_c, ycy_c, zcz_c, then we must have


0ğ¨c=ğ¨âˆ’d6ğ‘(001)

(xcyczc)=(oxâˆ’d6r13oyâˆ’d6r23ozâˆ’d6r33).
\begin{pmatrix} x_c \\ y_c \\ z_c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}
o_x - d_6r_{13} \\ o_y - d_6r_{23} \\ o_z - d_6r_{33}
\end{pmatrix}.




Using this equation, we may find the values of the first three joint variables.

This determines the orientation transformation 0ğ‘3{^0}\bm{R}_3, which depends only on these first three joint variables.

text:
Kinematic decoupling

Now that we have the rotation matrix 0ğ‘3{^0}\bm{R}_3 as a repercussion of the location of the wrist center oco_c from our previous discussion.
We can now determine the orientation of the end-effector relative to the frame Î£3\Sigma_3 from the expression ğ‘=0ğ‘33ğ‘6
\bm{R} = {^0}\bm{R}_3{^3}\bm{R}_6

The final three joint angles can then be found as a set of Euler angles corresponding to 3ğ‘6{^3}\bm{R}_6.








Geometry of kinematic decoupling


The vector ğ¨c\bm{o}_c is the position of the wrist center and ğ¨6\bm{o}_6 is the position of the end-effector both w.r.t the base frame.
The wrist center point coordinates do not depend on the wrist orientation variables Î¸4\theta_4, Î¸5\theta_5, and Î¸6\theta_6.

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Inverse position: a geometric approach

Most six-DoF manipulator designs are kinematically simple rendering the geometric approach simple and effective.

It is partly due to the difficulty of the general inverse kinematics problem that manipulator designs have evolved to their present state.

The complexity of the inverse kinematics problem increases with the number of nonzero DH parameters.

For most manipulators, many of the aia_i, did_i are zero, the Î±i\alpha_i are 00 or Â±Ï€2\pm \frac{\pi}{2}, etc.
In these cases especially, a geometric approach is simplest and most natural.

The general idea of the geometric approach is to solve for the joint variable qiq_i by projecting the manipulator onto the ğ±iâˆ’1âˆ’ğ²iâˆ’1\bm{x}_{i-1}-\bm{y}_{i-1} plane and solving a simple trigonometry problem.

For example, to solve for Î¸1\theta_1, we project the arm onto the ğ±0\bm{x}_0-ğ²0\bm{y}_0 plane and use trigonometry to find Î¸1\theta_1.
We will illustrate this method with two important examples: the spherical (RRP) and the articulated (RRR) arms.

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Spherical configuration



Projecting ğ¨c\bm{o}_c onto the ğ±0âˆ’ğ²0\bm{x}_0-\bm{y}_0 plane, we see that Î¸1=arctan2(yc,xc)orÎ¸1=Ï€+arctan2(yc,xc). \theta_1 = \arctan_2{(y_c, x_c)} \quad \text{or} \quad \theta_1 = \pi +
\arctan_2{(y_c, x_c)}. 
These solutions for Î¸1\theta_1 are valid unless xc=yc=0x_c = y_c = 0, i.e., the manipulator is in a Singular configuration.

In this case ğ¨câ‹”ğ³0\bm{o}_c \pitchfork \bm{z}_0 as shown in bottom right.
Then any value of Î¸1\theta_1 leaves ğ¨c\bm{o}_c fixed.

With r2=xc2+yc2r^2 = x_c^2 + y_c^2 and s=zcâˆ’d1s = z_c - d_1, the angle Î¸2\theta_2 is found from the top figure as Î¸2=arctan2(s,r)+Ï€2. \theta_2 = \arctan_2{(s, r)} + \frac{\pi}{2}. 
The linear distance d3d_3 is found as d3=r2+s2=xc2+yc2+(zcâˆ’d1)2. d_3 = \sqrt{r^2 + s^2} = \sqrt{x_c^2 + y_c^2 + (z_c -d_1)^2}. 
Thus, we obtain two solutions to the inverse position kinematics as long as the wrist center does not intersect ğ³0\bm{z}_0.








First three joints of a spherical manipulator.

The wrist center lies on the ğ³0\bm{z}_0-axis.

Similar to the spherical manipulator, if xcycâ‰ 0x_cy_c \neq 0: Î¸1=arctan2(yc,xc)orÎ¸1=Ï€+arctan2(yc,xc). \theta_1 = \arctan_2{(y_c, x_c)} \quad \text{or} \quad \theta_1 = \pi +
\arctan_2{(y_c, x_c)}. 
If xc=yc=0x_c = y_c = 0 the configuration is singular and Î¸1\theta_1 can take any value.
If there is an offset dâ‰ 0d \neq 0 as shown, then the wrist center cannot intersect ğ³0\bm{z}_0.

In this case, we will have d2=dd_2 = d or d3=dd_3 = d and there will, in general, be only two solutions for Î¸1\theta_1.

Left arm configuration






Define: Ï•=arctan2(yc,xc),Î±=arctan2(d,r2âˆ’d2)=arctan2(d,xc2+yc2âˆ’d2).

Then, Î¸1=Î±+Î²\theta_1 = \alpha + \beta.

text:
Articulated configuration



To find the angles Î¸2\theta_2 and Î¸3\theta_3 for the elbow manipulator for a given Î¸1\theta_1, consider the plane formed by the second and third links as shown in the figure.
With r2=xc2+yc2âˆ’d2r^2 = x_c^2 + y_c^2 - d^2 and s=zcâˆ’d1s=z_c - d_1, apply the law of cosines to obtain cosÎ¸3=12a2a3(r2+s2âˆ’a22âˆ’a32)=:D
\cos{\theta_3} = \frac{1}{2a_2a_3}\left(r^2 + s^2 - a_2^2 - a_3^2\right) =: D

Hence, Î¸3=arctan2(Â±1âˆ’D2,D)\theta_3 = \arctan_2{\left(\pm\sqrt{1-D^2}, D\right)}.
Once we know Î¸3\theta_3, we can use it to compute Î¸2\theta_2: Î¸2=arctan2(s,r)âˆ’arctan2(a3s3,a2+a3c3)=arctan2(zcâˆ’d1,xc2+yc2âˆ’d2)saflasjfâˆ’arctan2(a3s3,a2+a3c3).
\begin{aligned}
\theta_2 &= \arctan_2(s, r) - \arctan_2{(a_3s_3, a_2 + a_3c_3)} \\
&= \arctan_2{\left(z_c - d_1, \sqrt{x_c^2+y_c^2-d^2}\right)} \\

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Example: PUMA manipulator (articulated)



There are four solutions to the inverse position kinematics.
These correspond to the situations:

left arm â€“ elbow up,
left arm â€“ elbow down,
right arm â€“ elbow up,
right arm â€“ elbow down.

We will see that there are two solutions for the wrist orientation.
Thus, a total of eight solutions of the inverse kinematics problem exists for the PUMA manipulator.

title: 07_robot_arm_kinematics
text:
Inverse orientation
Â 
Â 

The inverse orientation problem is one of finding the values of the final three joint variables corresponding to a given orientation w.r.t. the frame Î£3\Sigma_3.
For a spherical wrist, this can be interpreted as the problem of finding a set of Euler angles corresponding to a given rotation matrix ğ‘\bm{R}.
We can therefore use the method developed all the way back in your youth, in Chapter 02, to solve for the three Euler angles Ï•\phi, Î¸\theta, Ïˆ\psi, and then use the mapping

Ï•â†¦Î¸4,Î¸â†¦Î¸5,Ïˆâ†¦Î¸6. 
\phi \mapsto \theta_4, \;\; \theta \mapsto \theta_5, \;\; \psi \mapsto \theta_6.

where D=xc2+yc2âˆ’d2+(zcâˆ’d1)2âˆ’a22âˆ’a322a2a3D = \frac{x_c^2 + y_c^2 - d^2 + (z_c - d_1)^2 - a_2^2 - a_3^2}{2a_2a_3}.
